title: Troponin-only Manchester Acute Coronary Syndromes (T-MACS) Decision Aid
description: Rules out acute coronary syndrome using high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T and clinical factors. Provides risk stratification for patients presenting with chest pain to the emergency department.

parameters.name: hs_ctnt_ng_l
parameters.description: High-sensitivity cardiac troponin T concentration on arrival

parameters.name: ekg_ischemia
parameters.description: Presence of ischemic changes on EKG

parameters.name: pain_right_arm
parameters.description: Pain radiating to right arm or shoulder

ranges.interpretation: Very low risk (<2% probability) of acute coronary syndrome. ACS can be ruled out. Consider discharge with appropriate safety netting and outpatient follow-up if clinically appropriate.
Low risk (2-5% probability) of acute coronary syndrome. Consider serial troponin measurement in the emergency department or observation unit to further stratify risk.

Moderate risk (5-95% probability) of acute coronary syndrome. Requires further evaluation with serial troponin measurements. Consider stress testing or CT coronary angiography for risk stratification.
High risk (â‰¥95% probability) of acute coronary syndrome. ACS is ruled in. Refer to cardiology immediately and initiate appropriate ACS treatment protocols.

references: Body R, Carlton E, Sperrin M, et al. Troponin-only Manchester Acute Coronary Syndromes (T-MACS) decision aid: single biomarker re-derivation and external validation in three cohorts. Emerg Med J. 2017;34(6):349-356.

Greenslade JH, Carlton EW, Van Hise C, et al. Diagnostic accuracy of the Troponin-only Manchester Acute Coronary Syndromes (T-MACS) decision aid with a point-of-care cardiac troponin assay. Acad Emerg Med. 2020;27(6):459-466.
formula: Probabilistic model using logistic regression incorporating high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T concentration and clinical risk factors
notes: Designed for use in emergency department patients presenting with chest pain suspicious for ACS
Uses only high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T (hs-cTnT) as biomarker, not serial measurements
Approximately 40% of patients can be classified as very low risk with <1% probability of ACS
Validated for use with point-of-care cardiac troponin assays
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and appropriate safety netting
Not applicable to patients with STEMI or obvious ACS on presentation
Requires troponin measurement on arrival, not serial measurements
Clinical factors include EKG changes, symptom characteristics, and hemodynamic status
Implementation has shown reduction in unnecessary hospital admissions
Superior performance compared to NICE guidelines for chest pain evaluation
